scene.title: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Good day, sir.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I am glad you're well.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I have not seen you long: how goes the world?

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: It wears, sir, as it grows.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, that's well known: But what particular rarity? what strange, Which manifold record not matches? See, Magic of bounty! all these spirits thy power Hath conjured to attend. I know the merchant.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I know them both; th' other's a jeweller.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, 'tis a worthy lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Nay, that's most fix'd.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: A most incomparable man, breathed, as it were, To an untirable and continuate goodness: He passes.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I have a jewel here--

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, pray, let's see't: for the Lord Timon, sir?

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: If he will touch the estimate: but, for that--

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'When we for recompense have praised the vile, It stains the glory in that happy verse Which aptly sings the good.'

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Tis a good form.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: And rich: here is a water, look ye.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedication To the great lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: A thing slipp'd idly from me. Our poesy is as a gum, which oozes From whence 'tis nourish'd: the fire i' the flint Shows not till it be struck; our gentle flame Provokes itself and like the current flies Each bound it chafes. What have you there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir. Let's see your piece.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Tis a good piece.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: So 'tis: this comes off well and excellent.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Indifferent.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Admirable: how this grace Speaks his own standing! what a mental power This eye shoots forth! how big imagination Moves in this lip! to the dumbness of the gesture One might interpret.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: It is a pretty mocking of the life. Here is a touch; is't good?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I will say of it, It tutors nature: artificial strife Lives in these touches, livelier than life.

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: How this lord is follow'd!

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: The senators of Athens: happy man!

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Look, more!

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: You see this confluence, this great flood of visitors. I have, in this rough work, shaped out a man, Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug With amplest entertainment: my free drift Halts not particularly, but moves itself In a wide sea of wax: no levell'd malice Infects one comma in the course I hold; But flies an eagle flight, bold and forth on, Leaving no tract behind.

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: How shall I understand you?

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I will unbolt to you. You see how all conditions, how all minds, As well of glib and slippery creatures as Of grave and austere quality, tender down Their services to Lord Timon: his large fortune Upon his good and gracious nature hanging Subdues and properties to his love and tendance All sorts of hearts; yea, from the glass-faced flatterer To Apemantus, that few things loves better Than to abhor himself: even he drops down The knee before him, and returns in peace Most rich in Timon's nod.

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I saw them speak together.

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill Feign'd Fortune to be throned: the base o' the mount Is rank'd with all deserts, all kind of natures, That labour on the bosom of this sphere To propagate their states: amongst them all, Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fix'd, One do I personate of Lord Timon's frame, Whom Fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her; Whose present grace to present slaves and servants Translates his rivals.

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Tis conceived to scope. This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks, With one man beckon'd from the rest below, Bowing his head against the sleepy mount To climb his happiness, would be well express'd In our condition.

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Nay, sir, but hear me on. All those which were his fellows but of late, Some better than his value, on the moment Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance, Rain sacrificial whisperings in his ear, Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him Drink the free air.

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, marry, what of these?

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants Which labour'd after him to the mountain's top Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down, Not one accompanying his declining foot.

speech.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Tis common: A thousand moral paintings I can show That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune's More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen The foot above the head.

speech.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself courteously to every suitor; a Messenger from VENTIDIUS talking with him; LUCILIUS and other servants following
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Imprison'd is he, say you?

speech.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself courteously to every suitor; a Messenger from VENTIDIUS talking with him; LUCILIUS and other servants following
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, my good lord: five talents is his debt, His means most short, his creditors most strait: Your honourable letter he desires To those have shut him up; which failing, Periods his comfort.

speech.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself courteously to every suitor; a Messenger from VENTIDIUS talking with him; LUCILIUS and other servants following
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Noble Ventidius! Well; I am not of that feather to shake off My friend when he must need me. I do know him A gentleman that well deserves a help: Which he shall have: I'll pay the debt, and free him.

speech.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself courteously to every suitor; a Messenger from VENTIDIUS talking with him; LUCILIUS and other servants following
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Your lordship ever binds him.

speech.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself courteously to every suitor; a Messenger from VENTIDIUS talking with him; LUCILIUS and other servants following
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Commend me to him: I will send his ransom; And being enfranchised, bid him come to me. 'Tis not enough to help the feeble up, But to support him after. Fare you well.

speech.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself courteously to every suitor; a Messenger from VENTIDIUS talking with him; LUCILIUS and other servants following
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: All happiness to your honour!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Freely, good father.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I have so: what of him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Attends he here, or no? Lucilius!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Here, at your lordship's service.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature, By night frequents my house. I am a man That from my first have been inclined to thrift; And my estate deserves an heir more raised Than one which holds a trencher.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Well; what further?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: One only daughter have I, no kin else, On whom I may confer what I have got: The maid is fair, o' the youngest for a bride, And I have bred her at my dearest cost In qualities of the best. This man of thine Attempts her love: I prithee, noble lord, Join with me to forbid him her resort; Myself have spoke in vain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: The man is honest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Does she love him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: She is young and apt: Our own precedent passions do instruct us What levity's in youth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Love you the maid?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: If in her marriage my consent be missing, I call the gods to witness, I will choose Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world, And dispossess her all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: How shall she be endow'd, if she be mated with an equal husband?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Three talents on the present; in future, all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: This gentleman of mine hath served me long: To build his fortune I will strain a little, For 'tis a bond in men. Give him thy daughter: What you bestow, in him I'll counterpoise, And make him weigh with her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Most noble lord, Pawn me to this your honour, she is his.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: My hand to thee; mine honour on my promise.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Humbly I thank your lordship: never may The state or fortune fall into my keeping, Which is not owed to you!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Vouchsafe my labour, and long live your lordship!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I thank you; you shall hear from me anon: Go not away. What have you there, my friend?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: A piece of painting, which I do beseech Your lordship to accept.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Painting is welcome. The painting is almost the natural man; or since dishonour traffics with man's nature, He is but outside: these pencill'd figures are Even such as they give out. I like your work; And you shall find I like it: wait attendance Till you hear further from me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: The gods preserve ye!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What, my lord! dispraise?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: A more satiety of commendations. If I should pay you for't as 'tis extoll'd, It would unclew me quite.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord, 'tis rated As those which sell would give: but you well know, Things of like value differing in the owners Are prized by their masters: believe't, dear lord, You mend the jewel by the wearing it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Well mock'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: No, my good lord; he speaks the common tongue, Which all men speak with him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Look, who comes here: will you be chid?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: We'll bear, with your lordship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: He'll spare none.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Good morrow to thee, gentle Apemantus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow; When thou art Timon's dog, and these knaves honest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Why dost thou call them knaves? thou know'st them not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Are they not Athenians?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Yes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Then I repent not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: You know me, Apemantus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Thou know'st I do: I call'd thee by thy name.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Thou art proud, Apemantus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Whither art going?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: To knock out an honest Athenian's brains.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: That's a deed thou'lt die for.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Right, if doing nothing be death by the law.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: How likest thou this picture, Apemantus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: The best, for the innocence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Wrought he not well that painted it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: He wrought better that made the painter; and yet he's but a filthy piece of work.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: You're a dog.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Thy mother's of my generation: what's she, if I be a dog?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: No; I eat not lords.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: An thou shouldst, thou 'ldst anger ladies.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, they eat lords; so they come by great bellies.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: That's a lascivious apprehension.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: So thou apprehendest it: take it for thy labour.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Not so well as plain-dealing, which will not cost a man a doit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What dost thou think 'tis worth?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Not worth my thinking. How now, poet!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: How now, philosopher!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Thou liest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Art not one?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Yes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Then I lie not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Art not a poet?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Yes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Then thou liest: look in thy last work, where thou hast feigned him a worthy fellow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: That's not feigned; he is so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thy labour: he that loves to be flattered is worthy o' the flatterer. Heavens, that I were a lord!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What wouldst do then, Apemantus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: E'en as Apemantus does now; hate a lord with my heart.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What, thyself?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Wherefore?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: That I had no angry wit to be a lord. Art not thou a merchant?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, Apemantus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Traffic confound thee, if the gods will not!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Traffic's thy god; and thy god confound thee!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What trumpet's that?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse, All of companionship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Pray, entertain them; give them guide to us. You must needs dine with me: go not you hence Till I have thank'd you: when dinner's done, Show me this piece. I am joyful of your sights. Most welcome, sir!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: So, so, there! Aches contract and starve your supple joints! That there should be small love 'mongst these sweet knaves, And all this courtesy! The strain of man's bred out Into baboon and monkey.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feed Most hungerly on your sight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Right welcome, sir! Ere we depart, we'll share a bounteous time In different pleasures. Pray you, let us in.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What time o' day is't, Apemantus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Time to be honest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: That time serves still.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: The more accursed thou, that still omitt'st it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Thou art going to Lord Timon's feast?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, to see meat fill knaves and wine heat fools.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Why, Apemantus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Shouldst have kept one to thyself, for I mean to give thee none.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Hang thyself!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding: make thy requests to thy friend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Away, unpeaceable dog, or I'll spurn thee hence!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I will fly, like a dog, the heels o' the ass.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: He's opposite to humanity. Come, shall we in, And taste Lord Timon's bounty? he outgoes The very heart of kindness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: He pours it out; Plutus, the god of gold, Is but his steward: no meed, but he repays Sevenfold above itself; no gift to him, But breeds the giver a return exceeding All use of quittance.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: The noblest mind he carries That ever govern'd man.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Long may he live in fortunes! Shall we in?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I'll keep you company.

scene.title: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.

speech.stagedir: Hautboys playing loud music. A great banquet served in; FLAVIUS and others attending; then enter TIMON, ALCIBIADES, Lords, Senators, and VENTIDIUS. Then comes, dropping, after all, APEMANTUS, discontentedly, like himself
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Most honour'd Timon, It hath pleased the gods to remember my father's age, And call him to long peace. He is gone happy, and has left me rich: Then, as in grateful virtue I am bound To your free heart, I do return those talents, Doubled with thanks and service, from whose help I derived liberty.

speech.stagedir: Hautboys playing loud music. A great banquet served in; FLAVIUS and others attending; then enter TIMON, ALCIBIADES, Lords, Senators, and VENTIDIUS. Then comes, dropping, after all, APEMANTUS, discontentedly, like himself
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, by no means, Honest Ventidius; you mistake my love: I gave it freely ever; and there's none Can truly say he gives, if he receives: If our betters play at that game, we must not dare To imitate them; faults that are rich are fair.

speech.stagedir: Hautboys playing loud music. A great banquet served in; FLAVIUS and others attending; then enter TIMON, ALCIBIADES, Lords, Senators, and VENTIDIUS. Then comes, dropping, after all, APEMANTUS, discontentedly, like himself
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: A noble spirit!

speech.stagedir: Hautboys playing loud music. A great banquet served in; FLAVIUS and others attending; then enter TIMON, ALCIBIADES, Lords, Senators, and VENTIDIUS. Then comes, dropping, after all, APEMANTUS, discontentedly, like himself
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Nay, my lords, Ceremony was but devised at first To set a gloss on faint deeds, hollow welcomes, Recanting goodness, sorry ere 'tis shown; But where there is true friendship, there needs none. Pray, sit; more welcome are ye to my fortunes Than my fortunes to me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord, we always have confess'd it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ho, ho, confess'd it! hang'd it, have you not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, Apemantus, you are welcome.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Fie, thou'rt a churl; ye've got a humour there Does not become a man: 'tis much to blame. They say, my lords, 'ira furor brevis est;' but yond man is ever angry. Go, let him have a table by himself, for he does neither affect company, nor is he fit for't, indeed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon: I come to observe; I give thee warning on't.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I scorn thy meat; 'twould choke me, for I should ne'er flatter thee. O you gods, what a number of men eat Timon, and he sees 'em not! It grieves me to see so many dip their meat in one man's blood; and all the madness is, he cheers them up too. I wonder men dare trust themselves with men: Methinks they should invite them without knives; Good for their meat, and safer for their lives. There's much example for't; the fellow that sits next him now, parts bread with him, pledges the breath of him in a divided draught, is the readiest man to kill him: 't has been proved. If I were a huge man, I should fear to drink at meals; Lest they should spy my windpipe's dangerous notes: Great men should drink with harness on their throats.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord, in heart; and let the health go round.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Flow this way! A brave fellow! he keeps his tides well. Those healths will make thee and thy state look ill, Timon. Here's that which is too weak to be a sinner, honest water, which ne'er left man i' the mire: This and my food are equals; there's no odds: Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods. Apemantus' grace. Immortal gods, I crave no pelf; I pray for no man but myself: Grant I may never prove so fond, To trust man on his oath or bond; Or a harlot, for her weeping; Or a dog, that seems a-sleeping: Or a keeper with my freedom; Or my friends, if I should need 'em. Amen. So fall to't: Rich men sin, and I eat root. Much good dich thy good heart, Apemantus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Captain Alcibiades, your heart's in the field now.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than a dinner of friends.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: So the were bleeding-new, my lord, there's no meat like 'em: I could wish my best friend at such a feast.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Would all those fatterers were thine enemies then, that then thou mightst kill 'em and bid me to 'em!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Might we but have that happiness, my lord, that you would once use our hearts, whereby we might express some part of our zeals, we should think ourselves for ever perfect.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, no doubt, my good friends, but the gods themselves have provided that I shall have much help from you: how had you been my friends else? why have you that charitable title from thousands, did not you chiefly belong to my heart? I have told more of you to myself than you can with modesty speak in your own behalf; and thus far I confirm you. O you gods, think I, what need we have any friends, if we should ne'er have need of 'em? they were the most needless creatures living, should we ne'er have use for 'em, and would most resemble sweet instruments hung up in cases that keep their sounds to themselves. Why, I have often wished myself poorer, that I might come nearer to you. We are born to do benefits: and what better or properer can we can our own than the riches of our friends? O, what a precious comfort 'tis, to have so many, like brothers, commanding one another's fortunes! O joy, e'en made away ere 't can be born! Mine eyes cannot hold out water, methinks: to forget their faults, I drink to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Thou weepest to make them drink, Timon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Joy had the like conception in our eyes And at that instant like a babe sprung up.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I promise you, my lord, you moved me much.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Much!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: What means that trump? How now?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Please you, my lord, there are certain ladies most desirous of admittance.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ladies! what are their wills?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: There comes with them a forerunner, my lord, which bears that office, to signify their pleasures.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I pray, let them be admitted.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all That of his bounties taste! The five best senses Acknowledge thee their patron; and come freely To gratulate thy plenteous bosom: th' ear, Taste, touch and smell, pleased from thy tale rise; They only now come but to feast thine eyes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: They're welcome all; let 'em have kind admittance: Music, make their welcome!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: You see, my lord, how ample you're beloved.

speech.stagedir: Music. Re-enter Cupid with a mask of Ladies as Amazons, with lutes in their hands, dancing and playing
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Hoy-day, what a sweep of vanity comes this way! They dance! they are mad women. Like madness is the glory of this life. As this pomp shows to a little oil and root. We make ourselves fools, to disport ourselves; And spend our flatteries, to drink those men Upon whose age we void it up again, With poisonous spite and envy. Who lives that's not depraved or depraves? Who dies, that bears not one spurn to their graves Of their friends' gift? I should fear those that dance before me now Would one day stamp upon me: 't has been done; Men shut their doors against a setting sun.

speech.stagedir: The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of TIMON; and to show their loves, each singles out an Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hautboys, and cease
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.

speech.stagedir: The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of TIMON; and to show their loves, each singles out an Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hautboys, and cease
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord, you take us even at the best.

speech.stagedir: The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of TIMON; and to show their loves, each singles out an Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hautboys, and cease
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Faith, for the worst is filthy; and would not hold taking, I doubt me.

speech.stagedir: The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of TIMON; and to show their loves, each singles out an Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hautboys, and cease
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you: Please you to dispose yourselves.

speech.stagedir: The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of TIMON; and to show their loves, each singles out an Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hautboys, and cease
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Most thankfully, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Flavius.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: The little casket bring me hither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Yes, my lord. More jewels yet! There is no crossing him in 's humour; Else I should tell him,--well, i' faith I should, When all's spent, he 'ld be cross'd then, an he could. 'Tis pity bounty had not eyes behind, That man might ne'er be wretched for his mind.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Where be our men?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Here, my lord, in readiness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Our horses!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: O my friends, I have one word to say to you: look you, my good lord, I must entreat you, honour me so much As to advance this jewel; accept it and wear it, Kind my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I am so far already in your gifts,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: So are we all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord, there are certain nobles of the senate Newly alighted, and come to visit you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: They are fairly welcome.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I beseech your honour, Vouchsafe me a word; it does concern you near.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Near! why then, another time I'll hear thee: I prithee, let's be provided to show them entertainment.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I scarce know how.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: May it please your honour, Lord Lucius, Out of his free love, hath presented to you Four milk-white horses, trapp'd in silver.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I shall accept them fairly; let the presents Be worthily entertain'd. How now! what news?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Please you, my lord, that honourable gentleman, Lord Lucullus, entreats your company to-morrow to hunt with him, and has sent your honour two brace of greyhounds.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I'll hunt with him; and let them be received, Not without fair reward.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: What will this come to? He commands us to provide, and give great gifts, And all out of an empty coffer: Nor will he know his purse, or yield me this, To show him what a beggar his heart is, Being of no power to make his wishes good: His promises fly so beyond his state That what he speaks is all in debt; he owes For every word: he is so kind that he now Pays interest for 't; his land's put to their books. Well, would I were gently put out of office Before I were forced out! Happier is he that has no friend to feed Than such that do e'en enemies exceed. I bleed inwardly for my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: You do yourselves Much wrong, you bate too much of your own merits: Here, my lord, a trifle of our love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: With more than common thanks I will receive it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, he's the very soul of bounty!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: And now I remember, my lord, you gave Good words the other day of a bay courser I rode on: it is yours, because you liked it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, I beseech you, pardon me, my lord, in that.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: You may take my word, my lord; I know, no man Can justly praise but what he does affect: I weigh my friend's affection with mine own; I'll tell you true. I'll call to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, none so welcome.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I take all and your several visitations So kind to heart, 'tis not enough to give; Methinks, I could deal kingdoms to my friends, And ne'er be weary. Alcibiades, Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich; It comes in charity to thee: for all thy living Is 'mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast Lie in a pitch'd field.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, defiled land, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: We are so virtuously bound--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: And so Am I to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: So infinitely endear'd--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: All to you. Lights, more lights!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: The best of happiness, Honour and fortunes, keep with you, Lord Timon!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ready for his friends.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but APEMANTUS and TIMON
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: What a coil's here! Serving of becks and jutting-out of bums! I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums That are given for 'em. Friendship's full of dregs: Methinks, false hearts should never have sound legs, Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on court'sies.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but APEMANTUS and TIMON
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Now, Apemantus, if thou wert not sullen, I would be good to thee.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but APEMANTUS and TIMON
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: No, I'll nothing: for if I should be bribed too, there would be none left to rail upon thee, and then thou wouldst sin the faster. Thou givest so long, Timon, I fear me thou wilt give away thyself in paper shortly: what need these feasts, pomps and vain-glories?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but APEMANTUS and TIMON
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Nay, an you begin to rail on society once, I am sworn not to give regard to you. Farewell; and come with better music.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: So: Thou wilt not hear me now; thou shalt not then: I'll lock thy heaven from thee. O, that men's ears should be To counsel deaf, but not to flattery!

speech.stagedir: Enter Senator, with papers in his hand
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A Senator's house.
speech.text: And late, five thousand: to Varro and to Isidore He owes nine thousand; besides my former sum, Which makes it five and twenty. Still in motion Of raging waste? It cannot hold; it will not. If I want gold, steal but a beggar's dog, And give it Timon, why, the dog coins gold. If I would sell my horse, and buy twenty more Better than he, why, give my horse to Timon, Ask nothing, give it him, it foals me, straight, And able horses. No porter at his gate, But rather one that smiles and still invites All that pass by. It cannot hold: no reason Can found his state in safety. Caphis, ho! Caphis, I say!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A Senator's house.
speech.text: Here, sir; what is your pleasure?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A Senator's house.
speech.text: Get on your cloak, and haste you to Lord Timon; Importune him for my moneys; be not ceased With slight denial, nor then silenced when-- 'Commend me to your master'--and the cap Plays in the right hand, thus: but tell him, My uses cry to me, I must serve my turn Out of mine own; his days and times are past And my reliances on his fracted dates Have smit my credit: I love and honour him, But must not break my back to heal his finger; Immediate are my needs, and my relief Must not be toss'd and turn'd to me in words, But find supply immediate. Get you gone: Put on a most importunate aspect, A visage of demand; for, I do fear, When every feather sticks in his own wing, Lord Timon will be left a naked gull, Which flashes now a phoenix. Get you gone.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A Senator's house.
speech.text: I go, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A Senator's house.
speech.text: 'I go, sir!'--Take the bonds along with you, And have the dates in contempt.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A Senator's house.
speech.text: I will, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A Senator's house.
speech.text: Go.

scene.title: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS, with many bills in his hand
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: No care, no stop! so senseless of expense, That he will neither know how to maintain it, Nor cease his flow of riot: takes no account How things go from him, nor resumes no care Of what is to continue: never mind Was to be so unwise, to be so kind. What shall be done? he will not hear, till feel: I must be round with him, now he comes from hunting. Fie, fie, fie, fie!

speech.stagedir: Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of Isidore and Varro
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Good even, Varro: what, You come for money?

speech.stagedir: Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of Isidore and Varro
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Is't not your business too?

speech.stagedir: Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of Isidore and Varro
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: It is: and yours too, Isidore?

speech.stagedir: Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of Isidore and Varro
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: It is so.

speech.stagedir: Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of Isidore and Varro
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Would we were all discharged!

speech.stagedir: Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of Isidore and Varro
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I fear it.

speech.stagedir: Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of Isidore and Varro
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Here comes the lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: So soon as dinner's done, we'll forth again, My Alcibiades. With me? what is your will?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord, here is a note of certain dues.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Dues! Whence are you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Of Athens here, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Go to my steward.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Please it your lordship, he hath put me off To the succession of new days this month: My master is awaked by great occasion To call upon his own, and humbly prays you That with your other noble parts you'll suit In giving him his right.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Mine honest friend, I prithee, but repair to me next morning.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Nay, good my lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Contain thyself, good friend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: One Varro's servant, my good lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: From Isidore; He humbly prays your speedy payment.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: If you did know, my lord, my master's wants--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Twas due on forfeiture, my lord, six weeks And past.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Your steward puts me off, my lord; And I am sent expressly to your lordship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Give me breath. I do beseech you, good my lords, keep on; I'll wait upon you instantly. Come hither: pray you, How goes the world, that I am thus encounter'd With clamourous demands of date-broke bonds, And the detention of long-since-due debts, Against my honour?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Please you, gentlemen, The time is unagreeable to this business: Your importunacy cease till after dinner, That I may make his lordship understand Wherefore you are not paid.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Do so, my friends. See them well entertain'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Pray, draw near.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Stay, stay, here comes the fool with Apemantus: let's ha' some sport with 'em.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Hang him, he'll abuse us.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: A plague upon him, dog!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: How dost, fool?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Dost dialogue with thy shadow?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I speak not to thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: No,'tis to thyself. Come away.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: There's the fool hangs on your back already.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: No, thou stand'st single, thou'rt not on him yet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Where's the fool now?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: He last asked the question. Poor rogues, and usurers' men! bawds between gold and want!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What are we, Apemantus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Asses.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Why?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: That you ask me what you are, and do not know yourselves. Speak to 'em, fool.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: How do you, gentlemen?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Gramercies, good fool: how does your mistress?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: She's e'en setting on water to scald such chickens as you are. Would we could see you at Corinth!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Good! gramercy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Look you, here comes my mistress' page.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Why, how now, captain! what do you in this wise company? How dost thou, Apemantus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Would I had a rod in my mouth, that I might answer thee profitably.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Prithee, Apemantus, read me the superscription of these letters: I know not which is which.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Canst not read?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: No.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: There will little learning die then, that day thou art hanged. This is to Lord Timon; this to Alcibiades. Go; thou wast born a bastard, and thou't die a bawd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Thou wast whelped a dog, and thou shalt famish a dog's death. Answer not; I am gone.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: E'en so thou outrunnest grace. Fool, I will go with you to Lord Timon's.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Will you leave me there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: If Timon stay at home. You three serve three usurers?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay; would they served us!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: So would I,--as good a trick as ever hangman served thief.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Are you three usurers' men?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, fool.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I think no usurer but has a fool to his servant: my mistress is one, and I am her fool. When men come to borrow of your masters, they approach sadly, and go away merry; but they enter my mistress' house merrily, and go away sadly: the reason of this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I could render one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Do it then, that we may account thee a whoremaster and a knave; which not-withstanding, thou shalt be no less esteemed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What is a whoremaster, fool?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: A fool in good clothes, and something like thee. 'Tis a spirit: sometime't appears like a lord; sometime like a lawyer; sometime like a philosopher, with two stones moe than's artificial one: he is very often like a knight; and, generally, in all shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore to thirteen, this spirit walks in.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Thou art not altogether a fool.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Nor thou altogether a wise man: as much foolery as I have, so much wit thou lackest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: That answer might have become Apemantus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Aside, aside; here comes Lord Timon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Come with me, fool, come.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I do not always follow lover, elder brother and woman; sometime the philosopher.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Pray you, walk near: I'll speak with you anon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: You make me marvel: wherefore ere this time Had you not fully laid my state before me, That I might so have rated my expense, As I had leave of means?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: You would not hear me, At many leisures I proposed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Go to: Perchance some single vantages you took. When my indisposition put you back: And that unaptness made your minister, Thus to excuse yourself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: O my good lord, At many times I brought in my accounts, Laid them before you; you would throw them off, And say, you found them in mine honesty. When, for some trifling present, you have bid me Return so much, I have shook my head and wept; Yea, 'gainst the authority of manners, pray'd you To hold your hand more close: I did endure Not seldom, nor no slight cheques, when I have Prompted you in the ebb of your estate And your great flow of debts. My loved lord, Though you hear now, too late--yet now's a time-- The greatest of your having lacks a half To pay your present debts.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Let all my land be sold.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Tis all engaged, some forfeited and gone; And what remains will hardly stop the mouth Of present dues: the future comes apace: What shall defend the interim? and at length How goes our reckoning?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: To Lacedaemon did my land extend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: O my good lord, the world is but a word: Were it all yours to give it in a breath, How quickly were it gone!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: You tell me true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: If you suspect my husbandry or falsehood, Call me before the exactest auditors And set me on the proof. So the gods bless me, When all our offices have been oppress'd With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept With drunken spilth of wine, when every room Hath blazed with lights and bray'd with minstrelsy, I have retired me to a wasteful cock, And set mine eyes at flow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Prithee, no more.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Heavens, have I said, the bounty of this lord! How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants This night englutted! Who is not Timon's? What heart, head, sword, force, means, but is Lord Timon's? Great Timon, noble, worthy, royal Timon! Ah, when the means are gone that buy this praise, The breath is gone whereof this praise is made: Feast-won, fast-lost; one cloud of winter showers, These flies are couch'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Come, sermon me no further: No villanous bounty yet hath pass'd my heart; Unwisely, not ignobly, have I given. Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack, To think I shall lack friends? Secure thy heart; If I would broach the vessels of my love, And try the argument of hearts by borrowing, Men and men's fortunes could I frankly use As I can bid thee speak.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Assurance bless your thoughts!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: And, in some sort, these wants of mine are crown'd, That I account them blessings; for by these Shall I try friends: you shall perceive how you Mistake my fortunes; I am wealthy in my friends. Within there! Flaminius! Servilius!

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord? my lord?

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I will dispatch you severally; you to Lord Lucius; to Lord Lucullus you: I hunted with his honour to-day: you, to Sempronius: commend me to their loves, and, I am proud, say, that my occasions have found time to use 'em toward a supply of money: let the request be fifty talents.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: As you have said, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Lord Lucius and Lucullus? hum!

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Go you, sir, to the senators-- Of whom, even to the state's best health, I have Deserved this hearing--bid 'em send o' the instant A thousand talents to me.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I have been bold-- For that I knew it the most general way-- To them to use your signet and your name; But they do shake their heads, and I am here No richer in return.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Is't true? can't be?

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: They answer, in a joint and corporate voice, That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot Do what they would; are sorry--you are honourable,-- But yet they could have wish'd--they know not-- Something hath been amiss--a noble nature May catch a wrench--would all were well--'tis pity;-- And so, intending other serious matters, After distasteful looks and these hard fractions, With certain half-caps and cold-moving nods They froze me into silence.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: You gods, reward them! Prithee, man, look cheerly. These old fellows Have their ingratitude in them hereditary: Their blood is caked, 'tis cold, it seldom flows; 'Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind; And nature, as it grows again toward earth, Is fashion'd for the journey, dull and heavy. Go to Ventidius. Prithee, be not sad, Thou art true and honest; ingeniously I speak. No blame belongs to thee. Ventidius lately Buried his father; by whose death he's stepp'd Into a great estate: when he was poor, Imprison'd and in scarcity of friends, I clear'd him with five talents: greet him from me; Bid him suppose some good necessity Touches his friend, which craves to be remember'd With those five talents. That had, give't these fellows To whom 'tis instant due. Ne'er speak, or think, That Timon's fortunes 'mong his friends can sink.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.

scene.title: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.

speech.stagedir: FLAMINIUS waiting. Enter a Servant to him
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: I have told my lord of you; he is coming down to you.

speech.stagedir: FLAMINIUS waiting. Enter a Servant to him
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: I thank you, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: Here's my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: One of Lord Timon's men? a gift, I warrant. Why, this hits right; I dreamt of a silver basin and ewer to-night. Flaminius, honest Flaminius; you are very respectively welcome, sir. Fill me some wine. And how does that honourable, complete, free-hearted gentleman of Athens, thy very bountiful good lord and master?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: His health is well sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: I am right glad that his health is well, sir: and what hast thou there under thy cloak, pretty Flaminius?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: 'Faith, nothing but an empty box, sir; which, in my lord's behalf, I come to entreat your honour to supply; who, having great and instant occasion to use fifty talents, hath sent to your lordship to furnish him, nothing doubting your present assistance therein.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: La, la, la, la! 'nothing doubting,' says he? Alas, good lord! a noble gentleman 'tis, if he would not keep so good a house. Many a time and often I ha' dined with him, and told him on't, and come again to supper to him, of purpose to have him spend less, and yet he would embrace no counsel, take no warning by my coming. Every man has his fault, and honesty is his: I ha' told him on't, but I could ne'er get him from't.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: Please your lordship, here is the wine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: Flaminius, I have noted thee always wise. Here's to thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: Your lordship speaks your pleasure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: I have observed thee always for a towardly prompt spirit--give thee thy due--and one that knows what belongs to reason; and canst use the time well, if the time use thee well: good parts in thee. Get you gone, sirrah. Draw nearer, honest Flaminius. Thy lord's a bountiful gentleman: but thou art wise; and thou knowest well enough, although thou comest to me, that this is no time to lend money, especially upon bare friendship, without security. Here's three solidares for thee: good boy, wink at me, and say thou sawest me not. Fare thee well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: Is't possible the world should so much differ, And we alive that lived? Fly, damned baseness, To him that worships thee!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: Ha! now I see thou art a fool, and fit for thy master.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.
speech.text: May these add to the number that may scald thee! Let moulten coin be thy damnation, Thou disease of a friend, and not himself! Has friendship such a faint and milky heart, It turns in less than two nights? O you gods, I feel master's passion! this slave, Unto his honour, has my lord's meat in him: Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment, When he is turn'd to poison? O, may diseases only work upon't! And, when he's sick to death, let not that part of nature Which my lord paid for, be of any power To expel sickness, but prolong his hour!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Who, the Lord Timon? he is my very good friend, and an honourable gentleman.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: We know him for no less, though we are but strangers to him. But I can tell you one thing, my lord, and which I hear from common rumours: now Lord Timon's happy hours are done and past, and his estate shrinks from him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Fie, no, do not believe it; he cannot want for money.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: But believe you this, my lord, that, not long ago, one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus to borrow so many talents, nay, urged extremely for't and showed what necessity belonged to't, and yet was denied.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: How!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: I tell you, denied, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: What a strange case was that! now, before the gods, I am ashamed on't. Denied that honourable man! there was very little honour showed in't. For my own part, I must needs confess, I have received some small kindnesses from him, as money, plate, jewels and such-like trifles, nothing comparing to his; yet, had he mistook him and sent to me, I should ne'er have denied his occasion so many talents.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: See, by good hap, yonder's my lord; I have sweat to see his honour. My honoured lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Servilius! you are kindly met, sir. Fare thee well: commend me to thy honourable virtuous lord, my very exquisite friend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: May it please your honour, my lord hath sent--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Ha! what has he sent? I am so much endeared to that lord; he's ever sending: how shall I thank him, thinkest thou? And what has he sent now?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: I know his lordship is but merry with me; He cannot want fifty five hundred talents.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: But in the mean time he wants less, my lord. If his occasion were not virtuous, I should not urge it half so faithfully.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Dost thou speak seriously, Servilius?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Upon my soul,'tis true, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish myself against such a good time, when I might ha' shown myself honourable! how unluckily it happened, that I should purchase the day before for a little part, and undo a great deal of honoured! Servilius, now, before the gods, I am not able to do,--the more beast, I say:--I was sending to use Lord Timon myself, these gentlemen can witness! but I would not, for the wealth of Athens, I had done't now. Commend me bountifully to his good lordship; and I hope his honour will conceive the fairest of me, because I have no power to be kind: and tell him this from me, I count it one of my greatest afflictions, say, that I cannot pleasure such an honourable gentleman. Good Servilius, will you befriend me so far, as to use mine own words to him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Yes, sir, I shall.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Do you observe this, Hostilius?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Ay, too well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Why, this is the world's soul; and just of the same piece Is every flatterer's spirit. Who can call him His friend that dips in the same dish? for, in My knowing, Timon has been this lord's father, And kept his credit with his purse, Supported his estate; nay, Timon's money Has paid his men their wages: he ne'er drinks, But Timon's silver treads upon his lip; And yet--O, see the monstrousness of man When he looks out in an ungrateful shape!-- He does deny him, in respect of his, What charitable men afford to beggars.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: Religion groans at it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A public place.
speech.text: For mine own part, I never tasted Timon in my life, Nor came any of his bounties over me, To mark me for his friend; yet, I protest, For his right noble mind, illustrious virtue And honourable carriage, Had his necessity made use of me, I would have put my wealth into donation, And the best half should have return'd to him, So much I love his heart: but, I perceive, Men must learn now with pity to dispense; For policy sits above conscience.

scene.title: SCENE III. A room in Sempronius' house.

speech.stagedir: Enter SEMPRONIUS, and a Servant of TIMON's
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. A room in Sempronius' house.
speech.text: Must he needs trouble me in 't,--hum!--'bove all others? He might have tried Lord Lucius or Lucullus; And now Ventidius is wealthy too, Whom he redeem'd from prison: all these Owe their estates unto him.

speech.stagedir: Enter SEMPRONIUS, and a Servant of TIMON's
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. A room in Sempronius' house.
speech.text: My lord, They have all been touch'd and found base metal, for They have au denied him.

speech.stagedir: Enter SEMPRONIUS, and a Servant of TIMON's
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. A room in Sempronius' house.
speech.text: How! have they denied him? Has Ventidius and Lucullus denied him? And does he send to me? Three? hum! It shows but little love or judgment in him: Must I be his last refuge! His friends, like physicians, Thrive, give him over: must I take the cure upon me? Has much disgraced me in't; I'm angry at him, That might have known my place: I see no sense for't, But his occasion might have woo'd me first; For, in my conscience, I was the first man That e'er received gift from him: And does he think so backwardly of me now, That I'll requite its last? No: So it may prove an argument of laughter To the rest, and 'mongst lords I be thought a fool. I'ld rather than the worth of thrice the sum, Had sent to me first, but for my mind's sake; I'd such a courage to do him good. But now return, And with their faint reply this answer join; Who bates mine honour shall not know my coin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. A room in Sempronius' house.
speech.text: Excellent! Your lordship's a goodly villain. The devil knew not what he did when he made man politic; he crossed himself by 't: and I cannot think but, in the end, the villainies of man will set him clear. How fairly this lord strives to appear foul! takes virtuous copies to be wicked, like those that under hot ardent zeal would set whole realms on fire: Of such a nature is his politic love. This was my lord's best hope; now all are fled, Save only the gods: now his friends are dead, Doors, that were ne'er acquainted with their wards Many a bounteous year must be employ'd Now to guard sure their master. And this is all a liberal course allows; Who cannot keep his wealth must keep his house.

scene.title: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.

speech.stagedir: Enter two Servants of Varro, and the Servant of LUCIUS, meeting TITUS, HORTENSIUS, and other Servants of TIMON's creditors, waiting his coming out
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Well met; good morrow, Titus and Hortensius.

speech.stagedir: Enter two Servants of Varro, and the Servant of LUCIUS, meeting TITUS, HORTENSIUS, and other Servants of TIMON's creditors, waiting his coming out
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: The like to you kind Varro.

speech.stagedir: Enter two Servants of Varro, and the Servant of LUCIUS, meeting TITUS, HORTENSIUS, and other Servants of TIMON's creditors, waiting his coming out
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Lucius! What, do we meet together?

speech.stagedir: Enter two Servants of Varro, and the Servant of LUCIUS, meeting TITUS, HORTENSIUS, and other Servants of TIMON's creditors, waiting his coming out
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, and I think One business does command us all; for mine Is money.

speech.stagedir: Enter two Servants of Varro, and the Servant of LUCIUS, meeting TITUS, HORTENSIUS, and other Servants of TIMON's creditors, waiting his coming out
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: So is theirs and ours.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: And Sir Philotus too!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Good day at once.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Welcome, good brother. What do you think the hour?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Labouring for nine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: So much?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Is not my lord seen yet?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Not yet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I wonder on't; he was wont to shine at seven.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, but the days are wax'd shorter with him: You must consider that a prodigal course Is like the sun's; but not, like his, recoverable. I fear 'tis deepest winter in Lord Timon's purse; That is one may reach deep enough, and yet Find little.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I am of your fear for that.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I'll show you how to observe a strange event. Your lord sends now for money.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Most true, he does.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: And he wears jewels now of Timon's gift, For which I wait for money.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: It is against my heart.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Mark, how strange it shows, Timon in this should pay more than he owes: And e'en as if your lord should wear rich jewels, And send for money for 'em.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I'm weary of this charge, the gods can witness: I know my lord hath spent of Timon's wealth, And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Yes, mine's three thousand crowns: what's yours?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Five thousand mine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Tis much deep: and it should seem by the sun, Your master's confidence was above mine; Else, surely, his had equall'd. Enter FLAMINIUS.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: One of Lord Timon's men.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Flaminius! Sir, a word: pray, is my lord ready to come forth?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: No, indeed, he is not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: We attend his lordship; pray, signify so much.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I need not tell him that; he knows you are too diligent.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ha! is not that his steward muffled so? He goes away in a cloud: call him, call him.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Do you hear, sir?

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: By your leave, sir,--

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What do ye ask of me, my friend?

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: We wait for certain money here, sir.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, If money were as certain as your waiting, 'Twere sure enough. Why then preferr'd you not your sums and bills, When your false masters eat of my lord's meat? Then they could smile and fawn upon his debts And take down the interest into their gluttonous maws. You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up; Let me pass quietly: Believe 't, my lord and I have made an end; I have no more to reckon, he to spend.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ay, but this answer will not serve.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
