speech.text: If 'twill not serve,'tis not so base as you; For you serve knaves.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: How! what does his cashiered worship mutter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: No matter what; he's poor, and that's revenge enough. Who can speak broader than he that has no house to put his head in? such may rail against great buildings.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, here's Servilius; now we shall know some answer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair some other hour, I should derive much from't; for, take't of my soul, my lord leans wondrously to discontent: his comfortable temper has forsook him; he's much out of health, and keeps his chamber.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Many do keep their chambers are not sick: And, if it be so far beyond his health, Methinks he should the sooner pay his debts, And make a clear way to the gods.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Good gods!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: We cannot take this for answer, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Servilius, help! My lord! my lord!

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What, are my doors opposed against my passage? Have I been ever free, and must my house Be my retentive enemy, my gaol? The place which I have feasted, does it now, Like all mankind, show me an iron heart?

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Put in now, Titus.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord, here is my bill.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Here's mine.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: And mine, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: And ours, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: All our bills.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Knock me down with 'em: cleave me to the girdle.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Alas, my lord,-

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Cut my heart in sums.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Mine, fifty talents.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Tell out my blood.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Five thousand crowns, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Five thousand drops pays that. What yours?--and yours?

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord,--

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord,--

speech.stagedir: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Faith, I perceive our masters may throw their caps at their money: these debts may well be called desperate ones, for a madman owes 'em.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: They have e'en put my breath from me, the slaves. Creditors? devils!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: My dear lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: What if it should be so?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: My lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: I'll have it so. My steward!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Here, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: So fitly? Go, bid all my friends again, Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius: All, sirrah, all: I'll once more feast the rascals.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: O my lord, You only speak from your distracted soul; There is not so much left, to furnish out A moderate table.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
speech.text: Be't not in thy care; go, I charge thee, invite them all: let in the tide Of knaves once more; my cook and I'll provide.

scene.title: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: My lord, you have my voice to it; the fault's Bloody; 'tis necessary he should die: Nothing emboldens sin so much as mercy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: Most true; the law shall bruise him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: Honour, health, and compassion to the senate!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: Now, captain?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: I am an humble suitor to your virtues; For pity is the virtue of the law, And none but tyrants use it cruelly. It pleases time and fortune to lie heavy Upon a friend of mine, who, in hot blood, Hath stepp'd into the law, which is past depth To those that, without heed, do plunge into 't. He is a man, setting his fate aside, Of comely virtues: Nor did he soil the fact with cowardice-- An honour in him which buys out his fault-- But with a noble fury and fair spirit, Seeing his reputation touch'd to death, He did oppose his foe: And with such sober and unnoted passion He did behave his anger, ere 'twas spent, As if he had but proved an argument.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: You undergo too strict a paradox, Striving to make an ugly deed look fair: Your words have took such pains as if they labour'd To bring manslaughter into form and set quarrelling Upon the head of valour; which indeed Is valour misbegot and came into the world When sects and factions were newly born: He's truly valiant that can wisely suffer The worst that man can breathe, and make his wrongs His outsides, to wear them like his raiment, carelessly, And ne'er prefer his injuries to his heart, To bring it into danger. If wrongs be evils and enforce us kill, What folly 'tis to hazard life for ill!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: My lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: You cannot make gross sins look clear: To revenge is no valour, but to bear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: My lords, then, under favour, pardon me, If I speak like a captain. Why do fond men expose themselves to battle, And not endure all threats? sleep upon't, And let the foes quietly cut their throats, Without repugnancy? If there be Such valour in the bearing, what make we Abroad? why then, women are more valiant That stay at home, if bearing carry it, And the ass more captain than the lion, the felon Loaden with irons wiser than the judge, If wisdom be in suffering. O my lords, As you are great, be pitifully good: Who cannot condemn rashness in cold blood? To kill, I grant, is sin's extremest gust; But, in defence, by mercy, 'tis most just. To be in anger is impiety; But who is man that is not angry? Weigh but the crime with this.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: You breathe in vain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: In vain! his service done At Lacedaemon and Byzantium Were a sufficient briber for his life.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: What's that?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: I say, my lords, he has done fair service, And slain in fight many of your enemies: How full of valour did he bear himself In the last conflict, and made plenteous wounds!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: He has made too much plenty with 'em; He's a sworn rioter: he has a sin that often Drowns him, and takes his valour prisoner: If there were no foes, that were enough To overcome him: in that beastly fury He has been known to commit outrages, And cherish factions: 'tis inferr'd to us, His days are foul and his drink dangerous.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: He dies.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: Hard fate! he might have died in war. My lords, if not for any parts in him-- Though his right arm might purchase his own time And be in debt to none--yet, more to move you, Take my deserts to his, and join 'em both: And, for I know your reverend ages love Security, I'll pawn my victories, all My honours to you, upon his good returns. If by this crime he owes the law his life, Why, let the war receive 't in valiant gore For law is strict, and war is nothing more.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: We are for law: he dies; urge it no more, On height of our displeasure: friend or brother, He forfeits his own blood that spills another.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: Must it be so? it must not be. My lords, I do beseech you, know me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: How!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: Call me to your remembrances.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: What!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: I cannot think but your age has forgot me; It could not else be, I should prove so base, To sue, and be denied such common grace: My wounds ache at you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: Banish me! Banish your dotage; banish usury, That makes the senate ugly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: If, after two days' shine, Athens contain thee, Attend our weightier judgment. And, not to swell our spirit, He shall be executed presently.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
speech.text: Now the gods keep you old enough; that you may live Only in bone, that none may look on you! I'm worse than mad: I have kept back their foes, While they have told their money and let out Their coin upon large interest, I myself Rich only in large hurts. All those for this? Is this the balsam that the usuring senate Pours into captains' wounds? Banishment! It comes not ill; I hate not to be banish'd; It is a cause worthy my spleen and fury, That I may strike at Athens. I'll cheer up My discontented troops, and lay for hearts. 'Tis honour with most lands to be at odds; Soldiers should brook as little wrongs as gods.

scene.title: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: The good time of day to you, sir.

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I also wish it to you. I think this honourable lord did but try us this other day.

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Upon that were my thoughts tiring, when we encountered: I hope it is not so low with him as he made it seem in the trial of his several friends.

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: It should not be, by the persuasion of his new feasting.

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I should think so: he hath sent me an earnest inviting, which many my near occasions did urge me to put off; but he hath conjured me beyond them, and I must needs appear.

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: In like manner was I in debt to my importunate business, but he would not hear my excuse. I am sorry, when he sent to borrow of me, that my provision was out.

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I am sick of that grief too, as I understand how all things go.

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Every man here's so. What would he have borrowed of you?

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: A thousand pieces.

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: A thousand pieces!

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: What of you?

speech.stagedir: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending. Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: He sent to me, sir,--Here he comes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: With all my heart, gentlemen both; and how fare you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ever at the best, hearing well of your lordship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: The swallow follows not summer more willing than we your lordship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Nor more willingly leaves winter; such summer-birds are men. Gentlemen, our dinner will not recompense this long stay: feast your ears with the music awhile, if they will fare so harshly o' the trumpet's sound; we shall to 't presently.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I hope it remains not unkindly with your lordship that I returned you an empty messenger.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: O, sir, let it not trouble you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: My noble lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Ah, my good friend, what cheer?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: My most honourable lord, I am e'en sick of shame, that, when your lordship this other day sent to me, I was so unfortunate a beggar.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Think not on 't, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: If you had sent but two hours before,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Let it not cumber your better remembrance. Come, bring in all together.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: All covered dishes!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Royal cheer, I warrant you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Doubt not that, if money and the season can yield it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: How do you? What's the news?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Alcibiades is banished: hear you of it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Alcibiades banished!
Alcibiades banished!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: 'Tis so, be sure of it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: How! how!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I pray you, upon what?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: My worthy friends, will you draw near?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I'll tell you more anon. Here's a noble feast toward.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: This is the old man still.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Will 't hold? will 't hold?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: It does: but time will--and so--

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I do conceive.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Each man to his stool, with that spur as he would to the lip of his mistress: your diet shall be in all places alike. Make not a city feast of it, to let the meat cool ere we can agree upon the first place: sit, sit. The gods require our thanks. You great benefactors, sprinkle our society with thankfulness. For your own gifts, make yourselves praised: but reserve still to give, lest your deities be despised. Lend to each man enough, that one need not lend to another; for, were your godheads to borrow of men, men would forsake the gods. Make the meat be beloved more than the man that gives it. Let no assembly of twenty be without a score of villains: if there sit twelve women at the table, let a dozen of them be--as they are. The rest of your fees, O gods--the senators of Athens, together with the common lag of people--what is amiss in them, you gods, make suitable for destruction. For these my present friends, as they are to me nothing, so in nothing bless them, and to nothing are they welcome. Uncover, dogs, and lap.

speech.stagedir: The dishes are uncovered and seen to be full of warm water
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: What does his lordship mean?

speech.stagedir: The dishes are uncovered and seen to be full of warm water
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I know not.

speech.stagedir: The dishes are uncovered and seen to be full of warm water
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: May you a better feast never behold, You knot of mouth-friends I smoke and lukewarm water Is your perfection. This is Timon's last; Who, stuck and spangled with your flatteries, Washes it off, and sprinkles in your faces Your reeking villany. Live loathed and long, Most smiling, smooth, detested parasites, Courteous destroyers, affable wolves, meek bears, You fools of fortune, trencher-friends, time's flies, Cap and knee slaves, vapours, and minute-jacks! Of man and beast the infinite malady Crust you quite o'er! What, dost thou go? Soft! take thy physic first--thou too--and thou;-- Stay, I will lend thee money, borrow none. What, all in motion? Henceforth be no feast, Whereat a villain's not a welcome guest. Burn, house! sink, Athens! henceforth hated be Of Timon man and all humanity!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: How now, my lords!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Know you the quality of Lord Timon's fury?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Push! did you see my cap?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I have lost my gown.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: He's but a mad lord, and nought but humour sways him. He gave me a jewel th' other day, and now he has beat it out of my hat: did you see my jewel?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Did you see my cap?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Here 'tis.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Here lies my gown.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Let's make no stay.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Lord Timon's mad.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: I feel 't upon my bones.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
speech.text: One day he gives us diamonds, next day stones.

scene.title: SCENE I. Without the walls of Athens.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the walls of Athens.
speech.text: Let me look back upon thee. O thou wall, That girdlest in those wolves, dive in the earth, And fence not Athens! Matrons, turn incontinent! Obedience fail in children! slaves and fools, Pluck the grave wrinkled senate from the bench, And minister in their steads! to general filths Convert o' the instant, green virginity, Do 't in your parents' eyes! bankrupts, hold fast; Rather than render back, out with your knives, And cut your trusters' throats! bound servants, steal! Large-handed robbers your grave masters are, And pill by law. Maid, to thy master's bed; Thy mistress is o' the brothel! Son of sixteen, pluck the lined crutch from thy old limping sire, With it beat out his brains! Piety, and fear, Religion to the gods, peace, justice, truth, Domestic awe, night-rest, and neighbourhood, Instruction, manners, mysteries, and trades, Degrees, observances, customs, and laws, Decline to your confounding contraries, And let confusion live! Plagues, incident to men, Your potent and infectious fevers heap On Athens, ripe for stroke! Thou cold sciatica, Cripple our senators, that their limbs may halt As lamely as their manners. Lust and liberty Creep in the minds and marrows of our youth, That 'gainst the stream of virtue they may strive, And drown themselves in riot! Itches, blains, Sow all the Athenian bosoms; and their crop Be general leprosy! Breath infect breath, at their society, as their friendship, may merely poison! Nothing I'll bear from thee, But nakedness, thou detestable town! Take thou that too, with multiplying bans! Timon will to the woods; where he shall find The unkindest beast more kinder than mankind. The gods confound--hear me, you good gods all-- The Athenians both within and out that wall! And grant, as Timon grows, his hate may grow To the whole race of mankind, high and low! Amen.

scene.title: SCENE II. Athens. A room in Timon's house.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS, with two or three Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. A room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Hear you, master steward, where's our master? Are we undone? cast off? nothing remaining?

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS, with two or three Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. A room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Alack, my fellows, what should I say to you? Let me be recorded by the righteous gods, I am as poor as you.

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS, with two or three Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. A room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Such a house broke! So noble a master fall'n! All gone! and not One friend to take his fortune by the arm, And go along with him!

speech.stagedir: Enter FLAVIUS, with two or three Servants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. A room in Timon's house.
speech.text: As we do turn our backs From our companion thrown into his grave, So his familiars to his buried fortunes Slink all away, leave their false vows with him, Like empty purses pick'd; and his poor self, A dedicated beggar to the air, With his disease of all-shunn'd poverty, Walks, like contempt, alone. More of our fellows.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. A room in Timon's house.
speech.text: All broken implements of a ruin'd house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. A room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Yet do our hearts wear Timon's livery; That see I by our faces; we are fellows still, Serving alike in sorrow: leak'd is our bark, And we, poor mates, stand on the dying deck, Hearing the surges threat: we must all part Into this sea of air.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. A room in Timon's house.
speech.text: Good fellows all, The latest of my wealth I'll share amongst you. Wherever we shall meet, for Timon's sake, Let's yet be fellows; let's shake our heads, and say, As 'twere a knell unto our master's fortunes, 'We have seen better days.' Let each take some; Nay, put out all your hands. Not one word more: Thus part we rich in sorrow, parting poor. O, the fierce wretchedness that glory brings us! Who would not wish to be from wealth exempt, Since riches point to misery and contempt? Who would be so mock'd with glory? or to live But in a dream of friendship? To have his pomp and all what state compounds But only painted, like his varnish'd friends? Poor honest lord, brought low by his own heart, Undone by goodness! Strange, unusual blood, When man's worst sin is, he does too much good! Who, then, dares to be half so kind again? For bounty, that makes gods, does still mar men. My dearest lord, bless'd, to be most accursed, Rich, only to be wretched, thy great fortunes Are made thy chief afflictions. Alas, kind lord! He's flung in rage from this ingrateful seat Of monstrous friends, nor has he with him to Supply his life, or that which can command it. I'll follow and inquire him out: I'll ever serve his mind with my best will; Whilst I have gold, I'll be his steward still.

scene.title: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: O blessed breeding sun, draw from the earth Rotten humidity; below thy sister's orb Infect the air! Twinn'd brothers of one womb, Whose procreation, residence, and birth, Scarce is dividant, touch them with several fortunes; The greater scorns the lesser: not nature, To whom all sores lay siege, can bear great fortune, But by contempt of nature. Raise me this beggar, and deny 't that lord; The senator shall bear contempt hereditary, The beggar native honour. It is the pasture lards the rother's sides, The want that makes him lean. Who dares, who dares, In purity of manhood stand upright, And say 'This man's a flatterer?' if one be, So are they all; for every grise of fortune Is smooth'd by that below: the learned pate Ducks to the golden fool: all is oblique; There's nothing level in our cursed natures, But direct villany. Therefore, be abhorr'd All feasts, societies, and throngs of men! His semblable, yea, himself, Timon disdains: Destruction fang mankind! Earth, yield me roots! Who seeks for better of thee, sauce his palate With thy most operant poison! What is here? Gold? yellow, glittering, precious gold? No, gods, I am no idle votarist: roots, you clear heavens! Thus much of this will make black white, foul fair, Wrong right, base noble, old young, coward valiant. Ha, you gods! why this? what this, you gods? Why, this Will lug your priests and servants from your sides, Pluck stout men's pillows from below their heads: This yellow slave Will knit and break religions, bless the accursed, Make the hoar leprosy adored, place thieves And give them title, knee and approbation With senators on the bench: this is it That makes the wappen'd widow wed again; She, whom the spital-house and ulcerous sores Would cast the gorge at, this embalms and spices To the April day again. Come, damned earth, Thou common whore of mankind, that put'st odds Among the route of nations, I will make thee Do thy right nature. Ha! a drum? Thou'rt quick, But yet I'll bury thee: thou'lt go, strong thief, When gouty keepers of thee cannot stand. Nay, stay thou out for earnest.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: What art thou there? speak.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: A beast, as thou art. The canker gnaw thy heart, For showing me again the eyes of man!

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: What is thy name? Is man so hateful to thee, That art thyself a man?

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I am Misanthropos, and hate mankind. For thy part, I do wish thou wert a dog, That I might love thee something.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I know thee well; But in thy fortunes am unlearn'd and strange.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I know thee too; and more than that I know thee, I not desire to know. Follow thy drum; With man's blood paint the ground, gules, gules: Religious canons, civil laws are cruel; Then what should war be? This fell whore of thine Hath in her more destruction than thy sword, For all her cherubim look.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Thy lips rot off!

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I will not kiss thee; then the rot returns To thine own lips again.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: How came the noble Timon to this change?

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Noble Timon, What friendship may I do thee?

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: None, but to Maintain my opinion.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: What is it, Timon?

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Promise me friendship, but perform none: if thou wilt not promise, the gods plague thee, for thou art a man! if thou dost perform, confound thee, for thou art a man!

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I have heard in some sort of thy miseries.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Thou saw'st them, when I had prosperity.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I see them now; then was a blessed time.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: As thine is now, held with a brace of harlots.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Is this the Athenian minion, whom the world Voiced so regardfully?

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Art thou Timandra?

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Yes.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Be a whore still: they love thee not that use thee; Give them diseases, leaving with thee their lust. Make use of thy salt hours: season the slaves For tubs and baths; bring down rose-cheeked youth To the tub-fast and the diet.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Hang thee, monster!

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Pardon him, sweet Timandra; for his wits Are drown'd and lost in his calamities. I have but little gold of late, brave Timon, The want whereof doth daily make revolt In my penurious band: I have heard, and grieved, How cursed Athens, mindless of thy worth, Forgetting thy great deeds, when neighbour states, But for thy sword and fortune, trod upon them,--

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I prithee, beat thy drum, and get thee gone.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I am thy friend, and pity thee, dear Timon.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: How dost thou pity him whom thou dost trouble? I had rather be alone.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Why, fare thee well: Here is some gold for thee.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Keep it, I cannot eat it.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: When I have laid proud Athens on a heap,--

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Warr'st thou 'gainst Athens?

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Ay, Timon, and have cause.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: The gods confound them all in thy conquest; And thee after, when thou hast conquer'd!

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Why me, Timon?

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: That, by killing of villains, Thou wast born to conquer my country. Put up thy gold: go on,--here's gold,--go on; Be as a planetary plague, when Jove Will o'er some high-viced city hang his poison In the sick air: let not thy sword skip one: Pity not honour'd age for his white beard; He is an usurer: strike me the counterfeit matron; It is her habit only that is honest, Herself's a bawd: let not the virgin's cheek Make soft thy trenchant sword; for those milk-paps, That through the window-bars bore at men's eyes, Are not within the leaf of pity writ, But set them down horrible traitors: spare not the babe, Whose dimpled smiles from fools exhaust their mercy; Think it a bastard, whom the oracle Hath doubtfully pronounced thy throat shall cut, And mince it sans remorse: swear against objects; Put armour on thine ears and on thine eyes; Whose proof, nor yells of mothers, maids, nor babes, Nor sight of priests in holy vestments bleeding, Shall pierce a jot. There's gold to pay soldiers: Make large confusion; and, thy fury spent, Confounded be thyself! Speak not, be gone.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Hast thou gold yet? I'll take the gold thou givest me, Not all thy counsel.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Dost thou, or dost thou not, heaven's curse upon thee!

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Give us some gold, good Timon: hast thou more?
Give us some gold, good Timon: hast thou more?

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Enough to make a whore forswear her trade, And to make whores, a bawd. Hold up, you sluts, Your aprons mountant: you are not oathable, Although, I know, you 'll swear, terribly swear Into strong shudders and to heavenly agues The immortal gods that hear you,--spare your oaths, I'll trust to your conditions: be whores still; And he whose pious breath seeks to convert you, Be strong in whore, allure him, burn him up; Let your close fire predominate his smoke, And be no turncoats: yet may your pains, six months, Be quite contrary: and thatch your poor thin roofs With burthens of the dead;--some that were hang'd, No matter:--wear them, betray with them: whore still; Paint till a horse may mire upon your face, A pox of wrinkles!

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Well, more gold: what then? Believe't, that we'll do any thing for gold.
Well, more gold: what then? Believe't, that we'll do any thing for gold.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Consumptions sow In hollow bones of man; strike their sharp shins, And mar men's spurring. Crack the lawyer's voice, That he may never more false title plead, Nor sound his quillets shrilly: hoar the flamen, That scolds against the quality of flesh, And not believes himself: down with the nose, Down with it flat; take the bridge quite away Of him that, his particular to foresee, Smells from the general weal: make curl'd-pate ruffians bald; And let the unscarr'd braggarts of the war Derive some pain from you: plague all; That your activity may defeat and quell The source of all erection. There's more gold: Do you damn others, and let this damn you, And ditches grave you all!

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: More counsel with more money, bounteous Timon.
More counsel with more money, bounteous Timon.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: More whore, more mischief first; I have given you earnest.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Strike up the drum towards Athens! Farewell, Timon: If I thrive well, I'll visit thee again.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: If I hope well, I'll never see thee more.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I never did thee harm.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Yes, thou spokest well of me.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Call'st thou that harm?

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Men daily find it. Get thee away, and take Thy beagles with thee.

speech.stagedir: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: We but offend him. Strike!

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: That nature, being sick of man's unkindness, Should yet be hungry! Common mother, thou, Whose womb unmeasurable, and infinite breast, Teems, and feeds all; whose self-same mettle, Whereof thy proud child, arrogant man, is puff'd, Engenders the black toad and adder blue, The gilded newt and eyeless venom'd worm, With all the abhorred births below crisp heaven Whereon Hyperion's quickening fire doth shine; Yield him, who all thy human sons doth hate, From forth thy plenteous bosom, one poor root! Ensear thy fertile and conceptious womb, Let it no more bring out ingrateful man! Go great with tigers, dragons, wolves, and bears; Teem with new monsters, whom thy upward face Hath to the marbled mansion all above Never presented!--O, a root,--dear thanks!-- Dry up thy marrows, vines, and plough-torn leas; Whereof ungrateful man, with liquorish draughts And morsels unctuous, greases his pure mind, That from it all consideration slips! More man? plague, plague!

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I was directed hither: men report Thou dost affect my manners, and dost use them.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: 'Tis, then, because thou dost not keep a dog, Whom I would imitate: consumption catch thee!

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: This is in thee a nature but infected; A poor unmanly melancholy sprung From change of fortune. Why this spade? this place? This slave-like habit? and these looks of care? Thy flatterers yet wear silk, drink wine, lie soft; Hug their diseased perfumes, and have forgot That ever Timon was. Shame not these woods, By putting on the cunning of a carper. Be thou a flatterer now, and seek to thrive By that which has undone thee: hinge thy knee, And let his very breath, whom thou'lt observe, Blow off thy cap; praise his most vicious strain, And call it excellent: thou wast told thus; Thou gavest thine ears like tapsters that bid welcome To knaves and all approachers: 'tis most just That thou turn rascal; hadst thou wealth again, Rascals should have 't. Do not assume my likeness.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Were I like thee, I'ld throw away myself.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Thou hast cast away thyself, being like thyself; A madman so long, now a fool. What, think'st That the bleak air, thy boisterous chamberlain, Will put thy shirt on warm? will these moss'd trees, That have outlived the eagle, page thy heels, And skip where thou point'st out? will the cold brook, Candied with ice, caudle thy morning taste, To cure thy o'er-night's surfeit? Call the creatures Whose naked natures live in an the spite Of wreakful heaven, whose bare unhoused trunks, To the conflicting elements exposed, Answer mere nature; bid them flatter thee; O, thou shalt find--

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: A fool of thee: depart.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I love thee better now than e'er I did.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I hate thee worse.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Why?

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Thou flatter'st misery.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I flatter not; but say thou art a caitiff.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Why dost thou seek me out?

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: To vex thee.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Always a villain's office or a fool's. Dost please thyself in't?

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Ay.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: What! a knave too?

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: If thou didst put this sour-cold habit on To castigate thy pride, 'twere well: but thou Dost it enforcedly; thou'ldst courtier be again, Wert thou not beggar. Willing misery Outlives encertain pomp, is crown'd before: The one is filling still, never complete; The other, at high wish: best state, contentless, Hath a distracted and most wretched being, Worse than the worst, content. Thou shouldst desire to die, being miserable.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Not by his breath that is more miserable. Thou art a slave, whom Fortune's tender arm With favour never clasp'd; but bred a dog. Hadst thou, like us from our first swath, proceeded The sweet degrees that this brief world affords To such as may the passive drugs of it Freely command, thou wouldst have plunged thyself In general riot; melted down thy youth In different beds of lust; and never learn'd The icy precepts of respect, but follow'd The sugar'd game before thee. But myself, Who had the world as my confectionary, The mouths, the tongues, the eyes and hearts of men At duty, more than I could frame employment, That numberless upon me stuck as leaves Do on the oak, hive with one winter's brush Fell from their boughs and left me open, bare For every storm that blows: I, to bear this, That never knew but better, is some burden: Thy nature did commence in sufferance, time Hath made thee hard in't. Why shouldst thou hate men? They never flatter'd thee: what hast thou given? If thou wilt curse, thy father, that poor rag, Must be thy subject, who in spite put stuff To some she beggar and compounded thee Poor rogue hereditary. Hence, be gone! If thou hadst not been born the worst of men, Thou hadst been a knave and flatterer.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Art thou proud yet?

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Ay, that I am not thee.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I, that I was No prodigal.

speech.stagedir: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I, that I am one now: Were all the wealth I have shut up in thee, I'ld give thee leave to hang it. Get thee gone. That the whole life of Athens were in this! Thus would I eat it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Here; I will mend thy feast.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: First mend my company, take away thyself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: So I shall mend mine own, by the lack of thine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: 'Tis not well mended so, it is but botch'd; if not, I would it were.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: What wouldst thou have to Athens?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Thee thither in a whirlwind. If thou wilt, Tell them there I have gold; look, so I have.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Here is no use for gold.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: The best and truest; For here it sleeps, and does no hired harm.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Where liest o' nights, Timon?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Under that's above me. Where feed'st thou o' days, Apemantus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Where my stomach finds meat; or, rather, where I eat it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Would poison were obedient and knew my mind!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Where wouldst thou send it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: To sauce thy dishes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: The middle of humanity thou never knewest, but the extremity of both ends: when thou wast in thy gilt and thy perfume, they mocked thee for too much curiosity; in thy rags thou knowest none, but art despised for the contrary. There's a medlar for thee, eat it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: On what I hate I feed not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Dost hate a medlar?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Ay, though it look like thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: An thou hadst hated meddlers sooner, thou shouldst have loved thyself better now. What man didst thou ever know unthrift that was beloved after his means?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Who, without those means thou talkest of, didst thou ever know beloved?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Myself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I understand thee; thou hadst some means to keep a dog.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: What things in the world canst thou nearest compare to thy flatterers?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Women nearest; but men, men are the things themselves. What wouldst thou do with the world, Apemantus, if it lay in thy power?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Give it the beasts, to be rid of the men.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Wouldst thou have thyself fall in the confusion of men, and remain a beast with the beasts?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Ay, Timon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: A beastly ambition, which the gods grant thee t' attain to! If thou wert the lion, the fox would beguile thee; if thou wert the lamb, the fox would eat three: if thou wert the fox, the lion would suspect thee, when peradventure thou wert accused by the ass: if thou wert the ass, thy dulness would torment thee, and still thou livedst but as a breakfast to the wolf: if thou wert the wolf, thy greediness would afflict thee, and oft thou shouldst hazard thy life for thy dinner: wert thou the unicorn, pride and wrath would confound thee and make thine own self the conquest of thy fury: wert thou a bear, thou wouldst be killed by the horse: wert thou a horse, thou wouldst be seized by the leopard: wert thou a leopard, thou wert german to the lion and the spots of thy kindred were jurors on thy life: all thy safety were remotion and thy defence absence. What beast couldst thou be, that were not subject to a beast? and what a beast art thou already, that seest not thy loss in transformation!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: If thou couldst please me with speaking to me, thou mightst have hit upon it here: the commonwealth of Athens is become a forest of beasts.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: How has the ass broke the wall, that thou art out of the city?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Yonder comes a poet and a painter: the plague of company light upon thee! I will fear to catch it and give way: when I know not what else to do, I'll see thee again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: When there is nothing living but thee, thou shalt be welcome. I had rather be a beggar's dog than Apemantus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Thou art the cap of all the fools alive.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Would thou wert clean enough to spit upon!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: A plague on thee! thou art too bad to curse.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: All villains that do stand by thee are pure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: There is no leprosy but what thou speak'st.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: If I name thee. I'll beat thee, but I should infect my hands.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I would my tongue could rot them off!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Would thou wouldst burst!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Away, Thou tedious rogue! I am sorry I shall lose A stone by thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Beast!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Slave!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Toad!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Rogue, rogue, rogue! I am sick of this false world, and will love nought But even the mere necessities upon 't. Then, Timon, presently prepare thy grave; Lie where the light foam the sea may beat Thy grave-stone daily: make thine epitaph, That death in me at others' lives may laugh. O thou sweet king-killer, and dear divorce 'Twixt natural son and sire! thou bright defiler Of Hymen's purest bed! thou valiant Mars! Thou ever young, fresh, loved and delicate wooer, Whose blush doth thaw the consecrated snow That lies on Dian's lap! thou visible god, That solder'st close impossibilities, And makest them kiss! that speak'st with every tongue, To every purpose! O thou touch of hearts! Think, thy slave man rebels, and by thy virtue Set them into confounding odds, that beasts May have the world in empire!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Would 'twere so! But not till I am dead. I'll say thou'st gold: Thou wilt be throng'd to shortly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Throng'd to!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Ay.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Thy back, I prithee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Live, and love thy misery.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Long live so, and so die. I am quit. Moe things like men! Eat, Timon, and abhor them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Where should he have this gold? It is some poor fragment, some slender sort of his remainder: the mere want of gold, and the falling-from of his friends, drove him into this melancholy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: It is noised he hath a mass of treasure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Let us make the assay upon him: if he care not for't, he will supply us easily; if he covetously reserve it, how shall's get it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: True; for he bears it not about him, 'tis hid.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Is not this he?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Where?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: 'Tis his description.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: He; I know him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Save thee, Timon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Now, thieves?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Soldiers, not thieves.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Both too; and women's sons.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: We are not thieves, but men that much do want.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: We cannot live on grass, on berries, water, As beasts and birds and fishes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Nor on the beasts themselves, the birds, and fishes; You must eat men. Yet thanks I must you con That you are thieves profess'd, that you work not In holier shapes: for there is boundless theft In limited professions. Rascal thieves, Here's gold. Go, suck the subtle blood o' the grape, Till the high fever seethe your blood to froth, And so 'scape hanging: trust not the physician; His antidotes are poison, and he slays Moe than you rob: take wealth and lives together; Do villany, do, since you protest to do't, Like workmen. I'll example you with thievery. The sun's a thief, and with his great attraction Robs the vast sea: the moon's an arrant thief, And her pale fire she snatches from the sun: The sea's a thief, whose liquid surge resolves The moon into salt tears: the earth's a thief, That feeds and breeds by a composture stolen From general excrement: each thing's a thief: The laws, your curb and whip, in their rough power Have uncheque'd theft. Love not yourselves: away, Rob one another. There's more gold. Cut throats: All that you meet are thieves: to Athens go, Break open shops; nothing can you steal, But thieves do lose it: steal no less for this I give you; and gold confound you howsoe'er! Amen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Has almost charmed me from my profession, by persuading me to it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: 'Tis in the malice of mankind that he thus advises us; not to have us thrive in our mystery.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I'll believe him as an enemy, and give over my trade.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Let us first see peace in Athens: there is no time so miserable but a man may be true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: O you gods! Is yond despised and ruinous man my lord? Full of decay and failing? O monument And wonder of good deeds evilly bestow'd! What an alteration of honour Has desperate want made! What viler thing upon the earth than friends Who can bring noblest minds to basest ends! How rarely does it meet with this time's guise, When man was wish'd to love his enemies! Grant I may ever love, and rather woo Those that would mischief me than those that do! Has caught me in his eye: I will present My honest grief unto him; and, as my lord, Still serve him with my life. My dearest master!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Away! what art thou?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Have you forgot me, sir?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Why dost ask that? I have forgot all men; Then, if thou grant'st thou'rt a man, I have forgot thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: An honest poor servant of yours.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Then I know thee not: I never had honest man about me, I; all I kept were knaves, to serve in meat to villains.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: The gods are witness, Ne'er did poor steward wear a truer grief For his undone lord than mine eyes for you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: What, dost thou weep? Come nearer. Then I love thee, Because thou art a woman, and disclaim'st Flinty mankind; whose eyes do never give But thorough lust and laughter. Pity's sleeping: Strange times, that weep with laughing, not with weeping!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: I beg of you to know me, good my lord, To accept my grief and whilst this poor wealth lasts To entertain me as your steward still.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Had I a steward So true, so just, and now so comfortable? It almost turns my dangerous nature mild. Let me behold thy face. Surely, this man Was born of woman. Forgive my general and exceptless rashness, You perpetual-sober gods! I do proclaim One honest man--mistake me not--but one; No more, I pray,--and he's a steward. How fain would I have hated all mankind! And thou redeem'st thyself: but all, save thee, I fell with curses. Methinks thou art more honest now than wise; For, by oppressing and betraying me, Thou mightst have sooner got another service: For many so arrive at second masters, Upon their first lord's neck. But tell me true-- For I must ever doubt, though ne'er so sure-- Is not thy kindness subtle, covetous, If not a usuring kindness, and, as rich men deal gifts, Expecting in return twenty for one?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: No, my most worthy master; in whose breast Doubt and suspect, alas, are placed too late: You should have fear'd false times when you did feast: Suspect still comes where an estate is least. That which I show, heaven knows, is merely love, Duty and zeal to your unmatched mind, Care of your food and living; and, believe it, My most honour'd lord, For any benefit that points to me, Either in hope or present, I'ld exchange For this one wish, that you had power and wealth To requite me, by making rich yourself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: Look thee, 'tis so! Thou singly honest man, Here, take: the gods out of my misery Have sent thee treasure. Go, live rich and happy; But thus condition'd: thou shalt build from men; Hate all, curse all, show charity to none, But let the famish'd flesh slide from the bone, Ere thou relieve the beggar; give to dogs What thou deny'st to men; let prisons swallow 'em, Debts wither 'em to nothing; be men like blasted woods, And may diseases lick up their false bloods! And so farewell and thrive.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: O, let me stay, And comfort you, my master.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.
speech.text: If thou hatest curses, Stay not; fly, whilst thou art blest and free: Ne'er see thou man, and let me ne'er see thee.

scene.title: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: As I took note of the place, it cannot be far where he abides.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: What's to be thought of him? does the rumour hold for true, that he's so full of gold?

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Certain: Alcibiades reports it; Phrynia and Timandra had gold of him: he likewise enriched poor straggling soldiers with great quantity: 'tis said he gave unto his steward a mighty sum.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Then this breaking of his has been but a try for his friends.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Nothing else: you shall see him a palm in Athens again, and flourish with the highest. Therefore 'tis not amiss we tender our loves to him, in this supposed distress of his: it will show honestly in us; and is very likely to load our purposes with what they travail for, if it be a just true report that goes of his having.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: What have you now to present unto him?

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Nothing at this time but my visitation: only I will promise him an excellent piece.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: I must serve him so too, tell him of an intent that's coming toward him.

speech.stagedir: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Good as the best. Promising is the very air o' the time: it opens the eyes of expectation: performance is ever the duller for his act; and, but in the plainer and simpler kind of people, the deed of saying is quite out of use. To promise is most courtly and fashionable: performance is a kind of will or testament which argues a great sickness in his judgment that makes it.

speech.stagedir: TIMON comes from his cave, behind
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Excellent workman! thou canst not paint a man so bad as is thyself.

speech.stagedir: TIMON comes from his cave, behind
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: I am thinking what I shall say I have provided for him: it must be a personating of himself; a satire against the softness of prosperity, with a discovery of the infinite flatteries that follow youth and opulency.

speech.stagedir: TIMON comes from his cave, behind
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Must thou needs stand for a villain in thine own work? wilt thou whip thine own faults in other men? Do so, I have gold for thee.

speech.stagedir: TIMON comes from his cave, behind
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Nay, let's seek him: Then do we sin against our own estate, When we may profit meet, and come too late.

speech.stagedir: TIMON comes from his cave, behind
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.

speech.stagedir: TIMON comes from his cave, behind
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: I'll meet you at the turn. What a god's gold, That he is worshipp'd in a baser temple Than where swine feed! 'Tis thou that rigg'st the bark and plough'st the foam, Settlest admired reverence in a slave: To thee be worship! and thy saints for aye Be crown'd with plagues that thee alone obey! Fit I meet them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Hail, worthy Timon!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Our late noble master!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Have I once lived to see two honest men?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Sir, Having often of your open bounty tasted, Hearing you were retired, your friends fall'n off, Whose thankless natures--O abhorred spirits!-- Not all the whips of heaven are large enough: What! to you, Whose star-like nobleness gave life and influence To their whole being! I am rapt and cannot cover The monstrous bulk of this ingratitude With any size of words.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Let it go naked, men may see't the better: You that are honest, by being what you are, Make them best seen and known.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: He and myself Have travail'd in the great shower of your gifts, And sweetly felt it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Ay, you are honest men.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: We are hither come to offer you our service.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Most honest men! Why, how shall I requite you? Can you eat roots, and drink cold water? no.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: What we can do, we'll do, to do you service.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Ye're honest men: ye've heard that I have gold; I am sure you have: speak truth; ye're honest men.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: So it is said, my noble lord; but therefore Came not my friend nor I.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: So, so, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: E'en so, sir, as I say. And, for thy fiction, Why, thy verse swells with stuff so fine and smooth That thou art even natural in thine art. But, for all this, my honest-natured friends, I must needs say you have a little fault: Marry, 'tis not monstrous in you, neither wish I You take much pains to mend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Beseech your honour To make it known to us.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: You'll take it ill.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Most thankfully, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Will you, indeed?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Doubt it not, worthy lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: There's never a one of you but trusts a knave, That mightily deceives you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Do we, my lord?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Ay, and you hear him cog, see him dissemble, Know his gross patchery, love him, feed him, Keep in your bosom: yet remain assured That he's a made-up villain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: I know none such, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Nor I.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Look you, I love you well; I'll give you gold, Rid me these villains from your companies: Hang them or stab them, drown them in a draught, Confound them by some course, and come to me, I'll give you gold enough.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Name them, my lord, let's know them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: You that way and you this, but two in company; Each man apart, all single and alone, Yet an arch-villain keeps him company. If where thou art two villains shall not be, Come not near him. If thou wouldst not reside But where one villain is, then him abandon. Hence, pack! there's gold; you came for gold, ye slaves: You have work'd for me; there's payment for you: hence! You are an alchemist; make gold of that. Out, rascal dogs!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: It is in vain that you would speak with Timon; For he is set so only to himself That nothing but himself which looks like man Is friendly with him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Bring us to his cave: It is our part and promise to the Athenians To speak with Timon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: At all times alike Men are not still the same: 'twas time and griefs That framed him thus: time, with his fairer hand, Offering the fortunes of his former days, The former man may make him. Bring us to him, And chance it as it may.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Here is his cave. Peace and content be here! Lord Timon! Timon! Look out, and speak to friends: the Athenians, By two of their most reverend senate, greet thee: Speak to them, noble Timon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Thou sun, that comfort'st, burn! Speak, and be hang'd: For each true word, a blister! and each false Be as cauterizing to the root o' the tongue, Consuming it with speaking!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Worthy Timon,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: Of none but such as you, and you of Timon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: The senators of Athens greet thee, Timon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: I thank them; and would send them back the plague, Could I but catch it for them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
speech.text: O, forget What we are sorry for ourselves in thee. The senators with one consent of love Entreat thee back to Athens; who have thought On special dignities, which vacant lie For thy best use and wearing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
